sections.title: References

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: This requirement pertains to gene nomenclature within the text body and not to the reference section, where detailed citations are needed.
The reference section lists full titles and authors, which is standard practice; gene abbreviations are not necessary here.
Full gene names in titles and citations do not need capitalized formatting according to scientific manuscript submission standards.
The reference section does not deal with species-specific orthologous gene names, so this requirement is not relevant.
This best practice suggestion is irrelevant to the references section, which focuses on complete citation details rather than prose style.
The references section does not include detailed gene descriptions as seen in supporting article text.
There are no scientific names in the reference section needing italics; references follow standard citation formatting.
Consistency in English variant is essential across the article, including references due to editorial standards.
requirement_evaluations.evidence: The references maintain consistent use of language appropriate for academic articles.
requirement_evaluations.reasoning: All references are presented consistently, adhering to expected language standards for scientific citations.
requirement_evaluations.overlap_notes: No significant overlaps detected; references follow established journal citation styles.

requirement_evaluations.applicability_reasoning: First-person language is mainly applicable to the narrative sections of a text, not the references.

sections.meta_notes: References are consistently formatted in standard academic style, maintaining high clarity and adherence to grammatical guidelines.
